articles.headline: Oil Sands Effort Turns on a Fight Over a Road
articles.snippet: Big oil companies want to use a route in the American Northwest to ship loads of equipment, but residents object.
articles.abstract: Big oil companies want to use a route in the American Northwest to ship loads of equipment, but residents object.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOOSKIA, Idaho  As U.S. Highway 12 hugs the serpentine banks of the Clearwater and Lochsa Rivers here, road signs bear the silhouettes of the 19th-century explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, with Mr. Lewis pointing off into the distance.

articles.headline: Top Corporations Aid U.S. Chamber of Commerce Campaign
articles.snippet: Dow Chemical and Goldman Sachs are among the undisclosed donors to the group, which is advertising aggressively against Democrats.
articles.abstract: Dow Chemical and Goldman Sachs are among the undisclosed donors to the group, which is advertising aggressively against Democrats.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Mike McIntire and Don Van Natta Jr

articles.headline: Europe Tested as War Crimes Suspect Remains Free
articles.snippet: Some countries are softening on whether Ratko Mladic’s arrest should be required for Serbia’s entry to the European Union.
articles.abstract: Some countries are softening on whether Ratko Mladic’s arrest should be required for Serbia’s entry to the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELGRADE — After 15 years on the run — sometimes in plain sight at soccer matches and weddings and sometimes deep in the fabric of this secretive city — Europe’s most wanted war-crimes suspect, Ratko Mladic, is being hidden by no more than a handful of loyalists, most probably in a neighborhood of Communist-era housing towers, according to investigators and some of his past associates.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Doreen Carvajal

articles.headline: Two Takes at NPR and Fox on Juan Williams
articles.snippet: In firing Juan Williams, NPR said he wasn’t impartial, and by renewing his contract, Fox showed its preference for opinion.
articles.abstract: In firing Juan Williams, NPR said he wasn’t impartial, and by renewing his contract, Fox showed its preference for opinion.
articles.lead_paragraph: NPR’s decision on Wednesday to fire Juan Williams and Fox News Channel’s decision on Thursday to give him a new contract put into sharp relief the two forms of journalism that compete every day for Americans’ attention.

articles.headline: New Faces Enter Fray in Accounting
articles.snippet: New leaders of the American and international accounting rule-making boards will push for agreement on how banks should value their assets.
articles.abstract: New leaders of the American and international accounting rule-making boards will push for agreement on how banks should value their assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the great accounting fight of the past decade moves near to a conclusion that seems likely to satisfy no one, the cast of characters is suddenly changing. The two most important accounting bodies in the world will be under new leadership as they try to move on from bruising battles that have pitted them against banks, bank regulators and politicians.

articles.headline: New Way to Help Chickens Cross to Other Side
articles.snippet: Two chicken producers are switching to a system of killing their birds that they consider more humane.
articles.abstract: Two chicken producers are switching to a system of killing their birds that they consider more humane.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shoppers in the supermarket today can buy chicken free of nearly everything but adjectives. It comes free-range, cage-free, antibiotic-free, raised on vegetarian feed, organic, even air-chilled.

articles.headline: Credit Cards Soon to Get a Makeover
articles.snippet: Cards will soon have lights and buttons that allow users to choose to pay for items with reward points or credit.
articles.abstract: Cards will soon have lights and buttons that allow users to choose to pay for items with reward points or credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The simple credit card is about to get a makeover.

articles.headline: Pakistani Troops Linked to Abuses Will Lose Aid
articles.snippet: The cutoff of U.S. funds, an unusual rebuke, illustrates growing tensions with a country seen as a pivotal partner.
articles.abstract: The cutoff of U.S. funds, an unusual rebuke, illustrates growing tensions with a country seen as a pivotal partner.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration will withhold training and equipment for about a half-dozen Pakistani Army units that are believed to have killed unarmed prisoners and civilians during recent offensives against the Taliban, according to senior administration and Congressional officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Nations Agree on Need to Shrink Trade Imbalances
articles.snippet: The agreement is part of an American-brokered compromise on calming exchange-rate tensions.
articles.abstract: The agreement is part of an American-brokered compromise on calming exchange-rate tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representatives of the world’s largest economies, meeting in South Korea, reached tentative agreement early Saturday on the need to rein in trade imbalances, as part of an American-brokered compromise on calming exchange-rate tensions that have threatened to disrupt the uneven global recovery.
